description: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a progressive and degenerative joint disease. It is the most common cause of joint impairment in persons over age 50 and increases in prevalence with age.(1,6) There is X-ray  evidence of some OA in nearly all persons over age 65, even if not clinically evident(1,6)

OA is characterized by the loss of articular cartilage and reactive changes in the joint margins and the subchondral bone.(1) It is a spectrum of disease, caused by a combination of genetic, metabolic, mechanical, and biochemical factors that impact the joint and surrounding tissue(5)

Hand OA may involve any or all of the following joints –Trapeziometacarpal (basilar or TMC) joint/carpometacarpal (CMC) joint of the thumb: located at the base of the thumb(2,3,4) –Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint: the finger joint closest to the fingertip(2,3,4) –Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint: the middle joint of the finger(2,3,4) –The thumb CMC joint is more often involved than other CMC joints and the intercarpal joints(5,6)

American College of Rheumatology criteria for the classification of hand OA –Hand pain, aching, or stiffness and at least three of the following:(2) -Hard tissue enlargement of 2 or more of 10 selected joints(2) -Hard tissue enlargement of 2 or more DIP joints(2) -Fewer than 3 swollen metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints(2) -Deformity of at least 1 of 10 selected joints(2) _ _ Joint protection programs/education _ _ Energy-conservation strategies _ _ Environmental modifications _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveInitially, break ADL/ IADL tasks down into separate parts; with increased patient tolerance, have the patient perform progressively longer segments of each ADL/ IADL task at a timeUse same principles of task analysis and simplification to address other ADL/ IADL issues at home  Reduced hand/DIP joint/PIP joint/CMC joint of the thumb/wrist ROM and/or strengthIncrease and/or maintain hand/DIP joint/PIP joint/CMC joint of the thumb/wrist ROM and/or strengthFunctional training _ Hand exercise program _ _ Gentle AROM and/or PROM to the point of pain with gentle to no stretch depending on the individual patient _ _ Educate the patient regarding proper positioning and joint protection strategies _ _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Cryotherapy _ _ Thermotherapy _ _ Hand splinting _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveGradual progression of intensity of exercises; increase the resistance, frequency, and/or duration of each exercise as the patient’s strength increases; active- assisted ROM and strengthening exercises are progressed as toleratedExercise programs can be performed at home according to the treating therapist’s discretion. Presentation/signs and symptoms –Signs -The involved digits with OA vary. Some patients may have single joint (e.g., 1st CMC) involvement and some have multiple joint involvement (e.g., all DIP joints) -Bony enlargements at the DIP and PIP joints(1,3,4,7) -Heberden’s nodes can occur in the DIP joints(1,3,7) -Bouchard’s nodules can occur in the PIP joints(1,3,7) -Reduced ROM and strength -Decreased ROM, sometimes with pain at end range(1,3,7) -Weakness and atrophy of muscles acting on the involved joint(s)(1) -Crepitus can occur as a late sign(1,3,7) -Joint swelling and tenderness, not always present in OA, can occur along the joint margin if synovitis is present(1,4,7) –Symptoms -History of increased joint pain(1) -Pain that occurs after the use of a joint and increases over the course of the day(1,8) -Stiffness of less than 30 minutes duration (e.g., after prolonged disuse, with first use in the morning)(1,8) –Systemic signs and symptoms are absent in persons with hand OA(5)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

contraindications precautions to test: Palpation over joints should be gentle and repeated as few times as possible
The patient’s pain level should be respected. Activity should stop when the patient feels intolerable hand pain, fatigue, or discomfort
Note the most recent administration of pain and/or anti-inflammatory medications, as this can impact the level of function

causes: two forms of oa,primary and sec: Primary: Idiopathic, but usually associated with aging and overuse.(2,3) Classified according to clinical presentation(1)–Localized: the most common subtype in hand OA–Generalized: multiple major joints are affected (e.g., knee, hip, and hand)–Erosive: a more severe subtype

Secondary:due to any of the following–Trauma(1,5)–Childhood anatomic abnormalities(1,5)–Inheritable metabolic disorders (e.g., Wilson’s disease, alkaptonuria, hemochromatosis)(1,5)–Neuropathic arthropathy(1)–Hemophilic arthropathy(1)–Endocrine disorders (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism)(1,5)–Paget’s disease(1,5)–Noninfectiou inflammatory arthritis (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis [RA], spondyloarthropathies)(1,5)-For additional information on RA, see the series of Clinical Reviews  on this topic–Gout or pseudogout(1)–Septic or tuberculous arthritis(1,5)–History of surgery on the joint(2)–Calcium deposition(5)
pathogenesis: Joint cartilage loses elasticity and breaks down, causing friction between the bones, resulting in pain and stiffness.(2,3) Bonemarrow lesions (BMLs) may result due to the loss of cartilage; and the bone may thicken and/or form cysts or osteophytes(bone spurs).(2,3) Sometimes small pieces of the bone or cartilage detach and move as loose bodies in the joint space(2)

Although OA previously was thought to be a noninflammatory disease, the lining of the joint (synovium) can becomeinflamed in OA and create cytokines (inflammatory proteins), which further damage cartilage.(2,3,6) Inflammation ispresent in most patients with symptomatic OA.(6) Joint involvement in OA is typically asymmetrical(5)

Pathological findings of the bone in OA–Patchy cartilage damage and bony hypertrophy seen macroscopically(1)–Edema of the extracellular matrix and cartilage microcracks(1)–Fissuring and pitting (BMLs) of the subchondral bone(1)–Erosion and osteocartilaginous loose bodies(1)–Subchondral bone trabecular microfractures and sclerosis with osteophyte formation(1)–Degradation response produced by release of proteolytic enzymes, collagenolytic enzymes, prostaglandins, and immuneresponse(1)

The diagnosis of erosive OA of the hand is made based on presence of central erosions and collapse of the subchondralbone plate on radiographs of the interphalangeal joints. Individuals with erosive OA of the hand often experience greaterpain, increased functional limitations, and worse hand mobility than those with localized hand OA(22)
risk factors: Prolonged occupational or sports joint stress(1)
Injury to a joint due to trauma, surgery, infection, or inflammatory arthritis(1,2)
Sex (female sex is associated with increased risk of OA of the hand, especially after menopause)(1,2,5)
Inherited bone abnormalities or inherited traits (e.g., dysplasia, misalignment)(2)

Geographic location/climatic factors (specifically altitude, latitude, annual precipitation, mean temperature in the summer,and mean day duration in the winter) may be associated with increased symptoms.(9) However, researchers assessingthe impact of climate on exacerbations of pain in patients with knee OA found no correlation between climate changes(temperature, relative humidity, pressure, precipitation) and exacerbation of knee pain(41)

overall contraindications precautions: Special considerations required to most effectively evaluate and treat the patient with OA include increased awareness of pain, joint stiffness and deformity, and coping strategies
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

Note the most recent administration of pain and/or anti-inflammatory medications, as this can impact the level of function 28 to 20(36) -Medications for current illness/injury: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling symptoms? -Common medications for pain/inflammation used by persons with hand OA -Acetaminophen up to 1,000 mg,4 times daily(1,3,6)  -Topical NSAIDs are often a primary method of treatment(1,3) -If acetaminophen and topical NSAIDs are not effective, an oral NSAID such as a COX-2  inhibitor may be trialed(1,10) -Intraarticular injections of corticosteroids may be used as an adjunct to core treatment for relief of moderate to severe pain when oral medications fail(6,10) -Novel therapeutic approaches such as disease-modifying  drugs for OA are in the investigational stage. Sufficient data regarding efficacy and long-term  outcomes are lacking on these(6) -Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for this condition are the following: -Imaging(3) -X-rays  are usually normal in the early stages of OA, but as the disease progresses changes such as narrowed, asymmetrical joint space, osteophyte and/or cyst formation, and/or subchondral bony sclerosis can be observed(1) -If OA is associated with inflammation (particularly erosive OA), erosions can show on the surface of the PIP and DIP joints on X-ray(1) -X-ray  radiographs have been the standard imaging method for diagnosing hand OA and detecting osteophytes. Ultrasound and MRI have been found to be more sensitive, especially in the early stages of OA.Hybrid techniques (e.g., PET/MRI or PET/CT) are being explored for use in research activities.(42)Several radiographic scoring systems have been used to assess hand OA -Authors of two longitudinal MRI studies in Norway on the progression of hand OA found that incident joint tenderness was associated with increasing synovitis and BMLs, and that such MRI findings predict the development of erosions(37,38) -Joint aspiration -Sometimes used to distinguish OA from chronic inflammatory/RA(1) -In OA, the white blood cell (WBC) count is usually less than (<) 500 cells/mm3, with predominantly mononuclear cells; whereas in RA, WBC count is usually more than (>) 2,000 cells/mm3, with predominantly neutrophils(1) -Laboratory tests are usually not helpful in initial diagnosis but may be useful for monitoring kidney and GI function in patients taking NSAIDs(1) -Home remedies/alternative therapies:  Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help -Oral or topical capsaicin is sometimes effective for pain relief in hand OA(1) -Evidence is lacking on the safety and efficacy of supplements for reducing symptoms of OA. However,individuals with OA commonly use supplements, including glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate(1,6,10) -Previous therapy:  Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful –Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Is pain relieved with rest? Heat? Cold?(1) –Body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Note which joints are involved in the hand and throughout the body(1) –Nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) –Rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0 to 10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Pain is usually present in patients with hand OA.On a 0 to 100 mm V AS, pain is typically equal to or more than (≥) 40 mm(1) -In early stages of hand OA, pain is often gradual in onset, intermittent, and mild; pain intensity and frequency increase as the disease progresses(5) –Pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables –Sleep disturbance: Document number of awakenings/night related to this condition  –Other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness; red, inflamed joints; excessive swelling) –Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

Medical history –Past medical history -Previous history of same/similar diagnosis: Any history of prior hand dysfunction or surgery, or injury to the hand? -Does the patient have OA of any other joints in the body? -Authors of a study in the United States found that progression of hand OA was greater in patients with more joints affected(26) -Comorbid diagnoses:  Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders -Authors of a study in the United States found that upper-extremity  comorbidities worsened self-rated  hand function in patients with symptomatic TMC arthritis(30) -Medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) -Other symptoms:  Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

Social/occupational history –Patient’s goals:  Document what the patient hopes to accomplish with therapy and in general –Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s occupations and role(s) within his or her family?(8) -Document any daily occupations that involve repetitive use of the joints in the hand (e.g., twisting knobs, typing, knitting/crocheting) -Is patient currently employed? If so, is he or she planning to return to work? -What activities, hobbies, etc., does the patient enjoy?(8) –Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on the patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment -Document functional and participation limitations. Hand OA may limit the patient’s participation in everyday activities(21) -It is important to consider the patient’s view of his or her participation in ADLs, IADLs, functions of a job, and activities of leisure. For example, a patient with hand OA might switch from a weekly golf outing to a weekly happy hour at the bar; however, is the substituted activity/participation as satisfying or healthy for the patient? -If the patient’s participation in previously enjoyable activities (or those required by a job or self-care)  is not satisfactory, a therapy goal should be increased/improved participation in enjoyable activities –Living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. -Identify the patient’s caregiver or network of support(8) -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?(8)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical and/or surgical interventions for OA to date, including any prior braces or splints/orthoses that the patient has worn Conservative treatment usually includes a splint/orthosis, cortisone injections, and NSAIDs(1) Authors of a small study (N = 10 patients with TMC hand OA) in Germany found that intraarticular injection of plateletrich  plasma reduced hand pain and improved the Mayo Wrist score at 6months follow-up.  Handgrip strength did not change;however, pinch grip strength was significantly reduced(35) Surgery is sometimes indicated for advanced OA (e.g., osteotomy, debridement, removal of loose bodies, joint replacement, joint fusion)(1,8) DIP joint arthrodesis can relieve pain, correct deformity, and resolve joint instability in DIP joints that do not respond to medication and splinting(4) For the PIP joint, pain is the primary indication for surgery; implant arthroplasty can relieve pain and retain motion in the fingers(4) For the thumb CMC joint, a hand-based  thumb splint/orthosis with the IP joint of the thumb and fingers left free can be used. There are a variety of styles of prefabricated and customfabricated orthoses that are available to treat thumb CMC arthritis. Surgery may be indicated for persistent, unresponsive pain(4) Authors of a prospective, follow-up  study (N = 33 of patients who had received surgery for thumb CMC hand OA) in Norway found that 11 to 14 years after surgery thumb mobility was maintained (except for abduction), key pinch strength had declined, and the median Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score had improved from

relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices(8) -Grip strength, pinch strength, and overall muscle strength(8) -Extent of joint involvement, including ROM, pain, and deformities(8)  -Patient’s personal preferences and willingness/readiness to use a specific device(8) -Cost; patient’s ability to afford the device(8) –Devices frequently incorporated into therapy and/or daily life for individuals with hand OA -Reachers; long-handled  equipment(8) -Shoehorn(8) -Elastic shoelaces(8) -Dressing sticks; sock aids(8) -Lightweight or large-handled  eating utensils(8) -Adaptive writing instruments(8) -Adaptive kitchen and cooking equipment(8) -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard(8) -Text-to-speech  software(8) -Electric scissors or can openers(8) -Belted waist pack instead of handbag(8) -Car door opener(8) -Multipurpose knob turner(8) -Button hook/zipper pull
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks involving weight shifting. Consider using –Tinetti Balance Scale –Berg Balance Scale
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Refer to physician orders regarding any cardiac and exercise limitations
Assess heart rate (HR), blood pressure (BP), and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use Borg RPE Scale if indicated
Monitor breathing to assist in determining fatigue and endurance levels
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesIf significant swelling is noted in the hand and/or wrist, take measurements and document volume/circumferenceBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobilityan 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe the patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted)(5) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking -Is the patient able to use the affected hand for support during walking tasks, if needed?Assess and document integrity, stability, mobility, and deformity of the joints of the hand and wrist(5) –Note the presence of joint deformities in the fingers(5,8) -Heberden’s nodules can occur in the DIP joints(1,3,8) -Bouchard’s nodules can occur in the PIP joints(1,3,8) –When the CMC joint of the thumb is involved, there is pain and tenderness at the base of the joint; a squared appearance indicates subluxation of this joint(8) -swelling, heat, and/or redness (signs of inflammation)(8) -pain(8) -subluxation or dislocation(8)  -crepitus(8) -tendon rupture(8)Assess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities and hands, as well as coordination; describe the quality of movement –Observe manual dexterity; serial opposition or rapidly touching each finger to thumb in succession(8) -Motor Assessment Scale -Assesses motor function; includes disability and impairment measures; assessments include arm and hand movements, tone, and mobility -Arm Motor Ability Test (AMAT) -Evaluates arm functional ability and quality of movement; 28 tasks, including eating with a spoon, opening a jar, tying a shoelace, and using the telephone -Jebsen Test of Hand Function -Composed of 7 activities, including writing, turning over stacked index cards, simulated eating, moving empty and weighted cans, and picking up small objects -DASH Outcome Measure -30-item,  self-report  questionnaire designed to measure physical function and symptoms in individuals with musculoskeletal disorders of the upper extremity -For more information on the DASH, see  Clinical Review ... Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number T903177 The Moberg Pick-up  Test (MPUT)(34) Quick and inexpensive Involves the picking up, holding, manipulation, and identification of small objects –9-hole  peg test for fine motor control
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT on muscles with contractures, abnormal tone, or coordination issues –Assess grip force in functional tasks; use grasp meter/dynamometer if appropriate(8) –Evaluate hand strength bilaterally; note any differences between the hands(8) -An adapted sphygmomanometer might be more comfortable than a standard dynamometer, but further study is required to establish reliability and norms(8) –Pinch meter for pinch strength(8)
observation inspection palpation includi: Note any signs of skin breakdown, especially if the patient wears a splint/orthosis
Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations) assess if deficits noted with initial interview

Ocular motor screening includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision -Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts -Document use of eye patching
Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Note the patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal as well as memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) may be appropriate if deficits are suspected based on initial interview

contraindications precautions: Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation or with poor circulation, or slow-healing wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in BP; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in BP
Use caution in patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy in patients who have an aversion to cold may be counterproductive if being used to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Do not use laser with pregnant women, patients with epilepsy, or patients with infections
Do not use over the unclosed fontanelles of children
Do not use over cancerous lesions, the mediastinum, areas of impaired sensation, sympathetic ganglia, the vagus nerve, the gonads, the cornea, endocrine glands, or hemorrhaging lesions
Goggles with an appropriate optical density rating should be worn by the patient
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Excessive exercises aimed at achieving full flexion and opposition of the thumb can result in increased subluxation and pain in unstable joints; proceed with caution during pinch/grip strengthening exercises in patients with thumb CMC arthritis(28)

Electrotherapy contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(16)
Manual therapy  precautions/contraindications (may vary according to technique)
Modify therapeutic exercises to allow the patient to adapt for severe functional limitations (e.g., frailty, easy fatigability, poor balance/coordination with increased fall risk)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Hand OA/comprehensive hand therapy is essential to reduce disability in ADLs and IADLs associated with hand pain and dysfunction
assessment plan of care.rule out: The individual’s medical team will rule out other types of arthritis prior to diagnosing OA of the hand.(1) Other diagnoses to be ruled out include: neoplasm(5) osteomyelitis(5) occult fracture(5) aseptic necrosis(5) chondromalacia(5) soft tissue infection(5) bursitis(5) tendonitis(5) ligamentous injury(5) overuse injury(5) radiculopathy(5) neuropathy(5) polymyalgia rheumatica(5)
prognosis: OA is progressive and there is no cure; however, both pharmacological and nonpharmacological treatments can improve function and reduce pain(5) –In early stages, pain is usually relieved with rest, but in later stages pain may occur even at rest(1)
Osteophyte formation may occur as the OA progresses, especially at the joint margins, and in advanced stages there is often full-thickness  loss of cartilage to the underlying bone(1)
Advanced OA is associated with pain and disability. Long-term  use of medications for OA can lead to complications such as gastritis and renal insufficiency(1)
Erosive OA is associated with a poorer prognosis than localized OA(22)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist for ambulation, gait training, lower extremity strengthening/ROM program, especially if OA is also present in the joints of the lower extremities (hip, knee) Certified hand therapist (occupational therapist or physical therapist) Occupational therapist or orthotist for the fabrication of splints/orthoses, braces Wound care nurse or specialist if signs of pressure ulcers are present Case manager or social worker to address emotional, home, and/or equipment and financial needs and provide support Mental health professional if the patient presents with signs of depression or distress Pain specialist for intractable pain
treatment summary: The goals of rehabilitation for individuals with hand OA are to decrease pain, increase mobility of the joint(s), prevent and correct deformity, slow the progression of the disease, and increase function in ADLs and IADLs(2)
Authors of a 2018 systematic review of studies on conservative treatment for OA of finger joints found evidence that orthoses are effective for managing DIP involvement(19)

Authors of a 2017 systematic review of exercise for hand OA found low-quality  evidence supporting the benefit of exercise on pain, functional use, and joint stiffness. They found few studies and the number of subjects was also small, leading to wide confidence intervals in the estimates of the clinical effectiveness of the interventions(17)

Authors of a 2015 systematic review developed evidence-based recommendations for exercise in patients with hand OA and then conducted a cohort study(31)  –An upper-extremity  exercise program was developed and reviewed by a local panel of clinical experts. These exercises were then trialed with a cohort of patients and control subjects. The final exercise program incorporated feedback from this cohort –The main goals of their recommended exercise program are to increase hand ROM, improve grip and pinch strength, and increase CMC stability (if necessary) –The exercise program components include -shoulder flexion and extension strengthening -biceps curls -serial opposition -resisted thumb abduction and extension -grip strengthening -finger stretching

The European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) 2007 evidence-based recommendations for the management of hand OA were updated in 2018 by a task force consisting of healthcare providers and patients. The guidelines include the following recommendations and overarching principles:(25) –The goals of management include controlling symptoms (e.g., pain, stiffness) and maximizing function to improve engagement and QOL –Education should be provided that includes information about OA and the course of the disease, self-management,  and options for treatment –Optimal management of hand OA necessitates a combination of individualized pharmacological and nonpharmacological treatments provided by a multidisciplinary team –Treatment of hand OA should be individualized and include shared decision-making  with respect to -type of OA (e.g., erosive, post-traumatic)  and severity -joints involved -risk factors -localization and severity of deformities -presence of inflammation -pain, disability, and QOL -comorbidities and other medications –Education on joint protection strategies, ergonomics, energy conservation, use of assistive devices, and ROM/ strengthening exercises should be provided to all patients with hand OA –Long-term  orthosis use for 1st CMC hand OA for symptom relief should be considered –Use of topical treatments should be considered before systemic treatment. Use of oral analgesia (e.g., NSAIDs) should be for limited time periods –Chondroitin sulfate may be useful for pain relief and to increase functional UE use –Surgery may be appropriate for patients with continued pain with nonoperative treatment or structural abnormalities

Physical and occupational interventions for individuals with hand OA include –ADL/IADL training with assistive/adaptive equipment -Authors of an RCT in Norway found that persons with hand OA who were trained to use assistive technology had higher levels of satisfaction with the devices and performed significantly better in ADLs than those who were not trained to use assistive technology(18) –Energy-conservation  techniques –Joint protection -Authors of a 2018 systemic review found only very-low-quality  evidence comparing joint protection to usual care in the management of OA. Also, the changes in pain and functional use that were seen in these studies were too small to be clinically important. Other systematic reviews have reported that joint protection education is effective(40) -Joint protection strategies include(8) -Respect pain(8) -Maintain muscle strength(8) -Maintain joint ROM; use each joint in its most stable and anatomical/functional plane(8) -Avoid positions of deformity(8)  -Use the strongest joints possible for each task(8) -Ensure the correct pattern of movement in activities(8) -Avoid prolonged static positions(8) -Avoid participation in activities that can’t be stopped immediately if they become too stressful(8) -Balance activity with adequate rest(8) -Reduce the force and effort used in all tasks (with assistive devices as needed)(8) –Strengthening exercises(10) -Authors of a 2017 systematic review of exercise for hand OA found that evidence for exercises was low-qualityand showed small to moderate beneficial effects.(17)Similarly, authors of a 2016 critical narrative review found that evidence is lacking for recommending specific therapeutic strengthening exercises in hand OA(33) -Authors of a crossover randomized trial (N = 76 participants, 55 to 93 years old, with hand OA) in Australia found that a daily 16-week  home-based exercise program had no significant effect on hand function or hand pain, stiffness, dexterity, and strength compared to a placebo intervention that consisted of using nonmedicated moisturizing hand lotion applied once daily(12) -Hand exercise program consisted of 9 exercises that took 15 minutes to complete. Primary outcome measure was AUSCAN -Nine of 12 grip and pinch strength measures did show statistically significant improvements in the exercise group, versus no measures showing improvements in placebo group -Authors of an RCT(N = 80 female subjects with hand OA) in Norway found that a 3-month,  home-based  hand exercise program significantly improved activity performance, grip strength, pain, and fatigue compared to the control group(28) -Strengthening and ROM exercises used rubber balls and bands; each participant was instructed to perform the home exercise sessions 3 times per week (10 repetitions of each exercise for the first 2 weeks, 12 repetitions for the second 2 weeks, and 15 repetitions for the remainder of the study).Exercises were well-tolerated -Authors of a 2017 Cochrane review of 5 trials with meta-analysis  (381 participants with hand OA) found that those in exercise groups had a small reduction in hand pain of 5% (1% to 9%, 0 to 10 V AS) on follow-up  compared with the control groups. They rated the overall quality of evidence as low for beneficial effects of exercise on hand pain(32) –Pain management with local heat or paraffin baths, cold, electromagnetic therapy, magnetotherapy, TENS as indicated(10,19) -Authors of a systematic review found evidence to support use of electromagnetic therapy, paraffin, and balneotherapy to decrease symptoms, including pain(19) -Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis found “silver-level”evidence  to support balneotherapy (i.e., use of mineral water, peloids, mud, and natural gases [carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, radon] for medical interventions) alone or in combination with magnetotherapy to improve function and decrease symptoms in patients with hand OA(20) –Environmental modifications(8) -Remove doors of cabinets or attach loops to cabinet door handles(8) -Replace doorknobs with lever handles(8) -Replace faucet handles with long-lever handles(8) -Use remote control devices or automatic on/off timers for electrical devices that use switches(8) -Use hands-free  speaker phone or Bluetooth(8) -Attach forearm and wrist supports to the computer(8) –Patient and family education –Education for self-management  of OA(19,25) -Self-management  strategies for persons with hand OA include exercising (ROM and strengthening exercises), topical management (e.g., heat/warmth, icing joints as needed), using splints, and using adaptive or assistive equipment –Splinting/orthosis fabrication for the hand as indicated(4,10) -Use of a hand splint/orthosis to stabilize the CMC joint of the thumb in palmar abduction to balance forces on the unstable joint(8)  -Authors of a prospective, radiologist-blinded, nonrandomized, internally controlled trial (N = 26 persons with painful and deformed DIP joint hand OA) in the United Kingdom found that a custom nighttime splint of the DIP joint improved average pain and worst pain, as well as extension lag deformity(23) -For each subject, an intervention DIP joint and a control DIP joint were selected. Subjects wore a custom, thermoplastic gutter splint every night for 3 months on the intervention joint. Clinical and radiological assessments were taken at baseline and again at 3 and 6 months -At 3 months, average pain and worst pain in the intervention joint (but not the control joint) were both significantly improved compared to baseline. Additionally, extension lag deformity was significantly improved in intervention joints at 6 months compared to control joints. Compliance was good, as only 4 subjects reporting poor adherence to the wearing schedule; 3/4 of these subjects improved adherence following a splint adjustment at 6 weeks -Authors of an RCT (N = 25 patients with CMC hand OA) in Iran found that pain (V AS) decreased 20% in the group that wore a custom-made  orthosis for 4 weeks, compared to a 3% reduction in the control group(39) . maintenance or prevention: Early diagnosis of OA with early intervention and medications for pain management can help prevent secondary complications and disability(10)
Maintaining the proper intake of vitamin D may prevent OA or slow its progression(3)
Reducing impact and load on a joint affected by OA can reduce symptoms and slow worsening of disability(6)
